Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of painted rock art on a sandstone rock face, showing two cattle figures, painted and infilled. The cattle are both upright and facing right, with long white lyre-shaped horns and painted in bichrome brown and white. The two cows on are mature; on the left is the painted, infilled head and shoulder of a white calf in the same orientation, cut off the edge of the image at the trunk. At the bottom is the infilled head and shoulder of a mature bichrome brown and white cow with naturalistic coat pattern markings and white markings on the neck and muzzle (collar? Halter?). The cow is upright and facing left and is cut off the edge of the image at the shoulder. Magharat el-Kantara, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Detail of 2013,2034.81. Magharat el-Kantara is a cave where an overhang forms a low rock shelter. It is located on a promontory separating the Wadi Firaq from the Wadi Wassa in the southern part of the the Gilf Kebir plateau in south-west Egypt. It is the only known rock art site in the south-eastern part of Gilf Kebir. The cave and its cattle paintings were discovered by a member of an expedition led by W.B.K. Shaw in 1935, the account of which was published in Antiquity. It was later investigated by Giancarlo Negro and Yves Gauthier in 1997.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
